metadata.titleEn: Geochemical data of major and trace elements of the getengling pluton in northeastern Hunan
metadata.description: In 2019, the major and trace element analysis of the getengling pluton was completed in the State Key Laboratory of isotope geochemistry, Guangzhou Institute of geochemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences. X-ray fluorescence spectrometry (XRF) was used for the analysis. The instrument model is RIGAKU zsx100e, and the accuracy of major element analysis is better than 5%. See Li Xianhua and Liu Ying (2002) for the specific process. Plasma mass spectrometry (ICPMS) was used for trace element analysis. The model is Perkin Elmer SCIEX Elan drc-e, and the analysis accuracy is better than 5%. The specific analysis method and process can be seen in Liu Ying and Liu Haichen (1996) and Liang Xirong et al. (2000)
metadata.instructions: Stored in word format, the sample name is "YY DD", where YY represents the sampling location and DD represents the sample number.

Revisiting the ca. 845–820-Ma S-type granitic magmatism in the Jiangnan Orogen: new insights on the Neoproterozoic tectono-magmatic evolution of South China. International Geology Review, 61(4), 383-403.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used for analyzing major and trace elements in geological samples from igneous bodies?
Example.Answer: An example of a data collection method used for analyzing major and trace elements in geological samples from igneous bodies is the use of X-ray fluorescence spectroscopy (XRF) for major element analysis, with an instrument like the Rigaku ZSX100e, achieving precision better than 5%. For trace elements, inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICPMS) is used, with an instrument such as the Perkin-Elmer Sciex ELAN DRC-e, also achieving precision better than 5%.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristic methods and precision levels used for analyzing major and trace elements in geological samples related to the葛藤岭岩体？
Feature Specification.Answer: X-ray fluorescence spectrometry (XRF), Rigaku ZSX100e, precision better than 5%, inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICPMS), Perkin-Elmer Sciex ELAN DRC-e, precision better than 5%

Quantification.Question: What is the precision percentage of major element analysis using X-ray fluorescence spectrometry in a dataset focusing on geochemical data?

Definition.Question: What is the significance of using X-ray fluorescence (XRF) and inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICPMS) in geochemical data collection?
Definition.Answer: X-ray fluorescence (XRF) and inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICPMS) are significant in geochemical data collection as they provide high precision and accuracy for the analysis of major and trace elements in geological samples. XRF is used for major element analysis with precision better than 5%, while ICPMS is used for trace element analysis with similar precision, allowing researchers to obtain detailed geochemical compositions of rock bodies.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to achieving high precision in major and trace element analysis in geochemical studies of rock bodies?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The use of advanced techniques like X-ray fluorescence spectroscopy (XRF) and inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICPMS) contributes to high precision, with specific instruments such as Rigaku ZSX100e and Perkin-Elmer Sciex ELAN DRC-e ensuring accuracy within 5%. Detailed methodologies outlined by researchers such as Li Xianhua and Liu Ying (2002), as well as Liu Ying and Liu Haichen (1996) and Liang Xirong et al. (2000), provide rigorous analytical frameworks.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the main objectives of employing X-ray fluorescence spectroscopy (XRF) and inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICPMS) in analyzing major and trace elements in geological studies of plutonic rock bodies?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The main objectives of employing X-ray fluorescence spectroscopy (XRF) and inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICPMS) in analyzing major and trace elements in geological studies are to achieve accurate and precise measurements of elemental compositions. XRF is used for major element analysis with a precision better than 5%, while ICPMS is used for trace element analysis, also with a precision better than 5%. These techniques help in understanding the geochemical characteristics and formation processes of plutonic rock bodies, such as the Getengling plutonic body in northeastern Hunan, and contribute to broader geological and geochemical research objectives.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the procedures and instrumental techniques used to ensure high precision in the analysis of major and trace elements in geological samples from rock bodies?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The analysis of major elements is conducted using X-ray fluorescence spectroscopy (XRF) with a Rigaku ZSX100e instrument, achieving an accuracy better than 5%. The trace elements are analyzed using inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICPMS) with a Perkin-Elmer Sciex ELAN DRC-e, also with an accuracy better than 5%. Detailed analysis methods and processes can be referred to in the works of Liu Ying and Liu Haichen (1996) and Liang Xirong et al. (2000).

Enablement.Question: What analytical techniques enable the precise measurement of major and trace elements in geological samples from the葛藤岭岩体?
Enablement.Answer: The precise measurement of major elements in geological samples from the葛藤岭岩体 is enabled by X-ray fluorescence spectroscopy (XRF), using the Rigaku ZSX100e instrument, which provides an accuracy better than 5%. For trace elements, the inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICPMS) method using the Perkin-Elmer Sciex ELAN DRC-e is employed, also offering an accuracy better than 5%.
